Urgent MRI is required to confirm a cervicomedullary junction lesion, define whether it is intrinsic, extra-axial, vascular or demyelinating, and guide neurosurgical versus medical treatment. Vascular imaging excludes malformations or dissection. Baseline blood tests look for metabolic myelopathies and systemic inflammation, while targeted autoimmune and antibody tests assess for demyelinating and granulomatous causes. CSF analysis and oligoclonal bands help distinguish multiple sclerosis or other inflammatory etiologies from neoplasm or infection, and evoked potentials look for additional demyelinating lesions.
